decision.reasoning:
Deep stats-focused analysis:

**Offensive matchups**: Seahawks offense (11th DVOA overall) led by Sam Darnold's elite NFC Champ performance (best game of his life, responding to prior middling play) vs. Patriots D (11th overall, ordinary regular season advanced metrics but elite playoffs: 6 explosives allowed in 3 games). Pats red zone D is a major weakness‚Äîideal for Seahawks to exploit with Darnold's playmaking and run tendencies (Pats may drop 7 in coverage to force runs). Pats offense (9th DVOA, #1 EPA/dropback, #2 Pass DVOA, elite success rate 59%) attacks dropbacks vs. Seahawks #1 defense, but SEA pass rush depth (5 players >40 pressures: Lawrence, Murphy II, Nwosu, Williams, Mafe) pressures imperfect Pats OL without needing perfection.

**Defensive matchups**: Seahawks #1 defense (FPI 7.0) schemes inside-out (DT strength, slot CB/box safety) vs. Pats run-weak offense (#21 DVOA run). Pats D limits explosives but vulnerable in red zone; Seahawks allowed 12 explosives to Rams but won via QB play‚ÄîPats secondary may struggle vs. SEA weapons like Jaxon Smith-Njigba.

**Key player matchups**: Seahawks pass rush depth vs. Pats OL; Darnold vs. Pats secondary (split-safety shells); Pats elite dropback passing vs. SEA front (Macdonald's philosophy favors interior pressure).

**Injury impact**: Drake Maye (shoulder) full participant 3 straight days‚Äîhealthy, no major concern. Seahawks' Darnold oblique minor; SEA LB Landry/OT Munford limited (knee) but not QB-critical.

**Historical patterns**: Super Bowls favor top FPI teams (SEA #1 vs. Pats #10); elite defenses win close games (both top-10 D); small ATS margins (SEA 14-5, Pats 13-6-1) suggest grinder, but top D/elite passing offenses correlate with ~65% win rate for #1 FPI side in playoffs.

**Coaching**: Mike Vrabel (Pats) big-game experience (player-turned-coach, chasing 7th Pats SB); Seahawks' staff leverages stats (Macdonald's scheme). Edge neutral, but SEA coaching in NFC Champ resilience.

**Intangibles**: Neutral venue (Super Bowl), no weather/travel edge; SEA higher motivation (2nd SB vs. Pats 7th?); Pats rest similar. Crowd neutral.

**Overall stats synthesis**: Seahawks #1 FPI (7.0) vs. Pats #10 (2.6); expert picks 82.8% SEA (48/58); spread -4.5 (sharps one-way SEA traffic, implies ~68% true prob); market at 61.1% undervalues SEA by ~7 pts based on FPI/diff, playoff D metrics, red zone exploits. Pats passing elite but SEA rush depth counters; no injury red flags. True prob SEA ~68-70%‚Äîclear mispricing, buy YES conviction on data divergence.

decision.raw:
<contrarian_case>
The bull case for the Patriots (NO shares) is robust when steel-manned: New England's defense has been elite in the playoffs, allowing just 6 explosive plays across 3 games against compromised offenses, while Seattle's defense surrendered 12 explosives to the Rams in the NFC Championship‚Äîexposing vulnerabilities in coverage and run defense. The Pats' offense ranks 3rd in DVOA and 1st in EPA/dropback & success rate on passes (2nd in Pass DVOA), perfectly suited to exploit Seattle's secondary weaknesses without needing a strong run game (21st in rush DVOA). A conservative Pats D (split-safety shells, force Seahawks to run/FGs) plays to their strengths, as Seattle's red-zone efficiency could be neutralized despite New England's regular-season weakness there. Drake Maye is fully healthy (shoulder full participant, no limitations), while Sam Darnold's "best game of his life" was a small-sample hot streak after 2 months of middling play and amid oblique injury concerns. Both teams top-10 FPI (SEA #1, NE #10), but Pats made the SB beating stronger schedules. Market at 60.7% YES overshot due to AI herding/anchoring on early Seahawk-favoring searches, info cascades, and model correlation‚Äîimplying 39% Pats when Vegas ML (+190) prices them ~30% and sharps bet Pats ML despite spread moving to SEA -4.5. Value on NO as pros with billions at stake see closer game; crowd wrong on overconfidence in SEA's #1 DPI ranking vs Pats' playoff-adjusted metrics.
</contrarian_case>

<reasoning>
The contrarian case is credible‚ÄîPats' playoff D dominance, elite pass metrics (1st EPA/dropback), and Maye's health provide real paths to upset, amplified by likely AI herding pushing market to 60.7% YES (above Vegas spread implied ~65-70%). However, stats still favor Seahawks overall (#1 FPI vs #10, #1 defense, Darnold's recent 1-game EPA outlier but positive trend, SEA 11th offense vs NE 9th). Pats' D faced injured/weak playoff foes; SEA's pass rush depth (5 players >40 pressures) threatens NE OL.
